pr_title: Add returning for insert to storage engine

timeline.message: Adapt InsertSourceGen to get all tests working (inefficient change)

timeline.body:
I am not sure if the `ShardResponse.CompressedResult` should have `resultValues`, it works, but seems to me semantically questionable. 
So we could consider using the full `ShardResponse` when using return values instead or an own dedicated datastructure.
timeline.bodyText:
I am not sure if the ShardResponse.CompressedResult should have resultValues, it works, but seems to me semantically questionable.
So we could consider using the full ShardResponse when using return values instead or an own dedicated datastructure.

timeline.author: mkleen

timeline.body: According to @mfussenegger this case should never happen since the `source` would be only null if it is created from a `FromRawInsertSource` which only applies to the `COPY` statement, which does not have a `returning` clause. However, this make sure values are only converted back from `BytesReference` to `Map<String, Object` if result values are requested.
timeline.bodyText: According to @mfussenegger this case should never happen since the source would be only null if it is created from a FromRawInsertSource which only applies to the COPY statement, which does not have a returning clause. However, this make sure values are only converted back from BytesReference to Map<String, Object if result values are requested.
timeline.bodyHTML: According to @mfussenegger this case should never happen since the source would be only null if it is created from a FromRawInsertSource which only applies to the COPY statement, which does not have a returning clause. However, this make sure values are only converted back from BytesReference to Map<String, Object if result values are requested.
timeline.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText: I think I was wrong. a INSERT INTO tbl (_raw) ... could probably also trigger this case.
replies.author: mfussenegger

timeline.body: This change is needed to be able to retrieve the result as `Map<String, Object>`. In all cases except the one in `FromRawInsertSource` the data is already in the form of `Map<String, Object>` which is needed for the returnvalue evaluation. Otherwise the values would need to converted again from `BytesReference`, which is unnecessary and expensive.
timeline.bodyText: This change is needed to be able to retrieve the result as Map<String, Object>. timeline.body: Minor: The type of outputs is defined in multiple ways over the codebase, sometimes it is `List<Symbol>` sometimes it is `List<? extends Symbol>` and sometimes it is `List<Field>`. Are there any cases where the output is not a `Field ` ?
timeline.bodyText: Minor: The type of outputs is defined in multiple ways over the codebase, sometimes it is List<Symbol> sometimes it is List<? extends Symbol> and sometimes it is List<Field>. Are there any cases where the output is not a Field  ?

timeline.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText: Yes, there can be function symbols or Reference symbols as well.

replies.bodyText: I forgot to mention it, this formatting is on purpose. Ceckstyle complains if i format the lambda aligned to the other values, which seems wrong to me. [ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /Users/mkleen/Code/crate/sql/src/main/java/io/crate/execution/dml/upsert/TransportShardUpsertAction.java:357: 'lambda arguments' has incorrect indentation level 24, expected level should be 20. [Indentation]
replies.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText:
I think the following passes:
diff --git a/sql/src/main/java/io/crate/execution/dml/upsert/TransportShardUpsertAction.java b/sql/src/main/java/io/crate/execution/dml/upsert/TransportShardUpsertAction.java
index 4001a79418..c9c1212316 100644
--- a/sql/src/main/java/io/crate/execution/dml/upsert/TransportShardUpsertAction.java
+++ b/sql/src/main/java/io/crate/execution/dml/upsert/TransportShardUpsertAction.java
@@ -347,13 +347,14 @@ public class TransportShardUpsertAction extends TransportShardAction<ShardUpsert
             returnvalues = returnGen.generateReturnValues(
                 // return -1 as docId, the docId can only be retrieved by fetching the inserted document again, which
                 // we want to avoid. The docId is anyway just valid with the lifetime of a searcher and can change afterwards.
-                new Doc(-1,
-                        indexShard.shardId().getIndexName(),
-                        item.id(),
-                        indexResult.getVersion(),
-                        indexResult.getSeqNo(),
-                        primaryTerm,
-                        source,
+                new Doc(
+                    -1,
+                    indexShard.shardId().getIndexName(),
+                    item.id(),
+                    indexResult.getVersion(),
+                    indexResult.getSeqNo(),
+                    primaryTerm,
+                    source,
                     () -> ""
                 )
             );
replies.author: mfussenegger

+                    item.id(),
+                    indexResult.getVersion(),
+                    indexResult.getSeqNo(),
+                    primaryTerm,
+                    source,
                     () -> ""
                 )
             );

replies.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText: Ah right, didn't see this in the diff.
replies.author: mfussenegger

timeline.body: What is the difference between `returnValues` and `outputs`? Isn't it redundant to have both?
timeline.bodyText: What is the difference between returnValues and outputs? Isn't it redundant to have both?
timeline.bodyHTML: What is the difference between returnValues and outputs? Isn't it redundant to have both?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText: They are not the same. outputs are the types of result e.g. long for rowcount, while returnValues are the expression of the returning clause evaluated against the document.
replies.author: mkleen

replies.bodyText:
But if returnValues are present, then the outputs must match. (Or at least have matching types).
I think this needs at least some clarification via comments how they relate to each other. Or maybe utilize the outputs for both and have some flag that indicates if it is a result set or a single rowcount.
replies.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText: I just tried your suggestion to use the outputs and a flag indicating what is the purpose of the outputs and it clearly does not make the code simpler, because now i have to treat outputs in different ways depending on the purpose. For now I added a comment with the relationship between output and returnvalues and will give it a second thought also related to updates. If we do this change we should probably do it also for update related datastructures to be consistent.
replies.author: mkleen

timeline.body:
Maybe limit this to only the one table that is used in the tests.

Wastes some CPU cycles and makes it more difficult to have an overview what schemas are in use in this file.
